author: Jasper Hamill
title: Lethal Predator drones to be 're-branded with soothing new name': Government accused of whitewash over killer flying robots
text:
Westminster has been accused of planning to change the name of the controversial Predator drone to the more reassuring-sounding Protector.
Activists claimed David Cameron was using this "soothing" moniker to distract the public from its purpose: the targeted killing of Britain's enemies on foreign soil.
Over the weekend, the Prime Minster said he would double the number of drones in the British fleet by buying 20 Protectors and scrapping the current model, which are called Reapers.
But experts expect the new flying killers to be American-made Predator B drones.
Chris Cole, a campaigner with Drone Wars, said: "The name points up the desperate desire of drone advocates to break the connection in the public’s mind between drones and targeted killing.
"Protector seeks to highlight armed drones being used for close air support – flying above soldiers out on patrol – rather than for tracking down and executing enemies."
Getty Technology: Drones are believed to have been used in strikes on ISIS
He said the name of drones was a "crucial issue in the debate" over whether it is right to use airborne assassin robots.
"Both the military and the drone industry have long fought a fruitless battle to get the media and the public to call them ‘Remotely Piloted Air Systems’," Cole continued.
"The desire to control the narrative around the use of drones in this way is almost certainly what has led the MoD to baptise this ‘new’ drone as the Protector, a far more soothing name than ‘Predator’ or ‘Reaper’."
David Cameron announced plans to buy 20 Protector drones in an interview with the Sunday Telegraph .
"One of the biggest threats we have to respond to is that terrorist threat and that means a lot of things in terms of obviously domestic security and our intelligence services," he said.
"But it also means making sure that we have the military equipment and resources we need - so seeing an enhancement of our Special Forces and particularly on the issue of surveillance aircraft."
The only drone which is called a Protector is made by the Israeli firm Rafael Advanced Defense Systems.
We understand Protector is actually the name of a government programme, which has not yet decided which model of drone it will actually buy.
The new drone will play a role in overseas surveillance and although a decision has not yet been reached on whether it will carry offensive weapons, it is highly likely the Protector will be able to kill.
